parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
Divine; subst: the Deity. From theos; godlike: - divine, godhead.
From dunamai; force; specially, miraculous power.

parse: Verb - Perfect Participle Middle or Passive - Genitive Feminine Singular
str2: To give, grant, donate. Middle voice from doron; to bestow gratuitously.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
To, towards, with. A strengthened form of pro; a preposition of direction; forward to, i.e. Toward.
Life, both of physical (present) and of spiritual (particularly future) existence. From zao; life.
And, even, also, namely.
Piety (towards God), godliness, devotion, godliness. From eusebes; piety; specially, the gospel scheme.
A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From epiginosko; recognition, i.e. full discernment, acknowledgement.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Genitive Masculine Singular
str2: (a) I call, summon, invite, (b) I call, name. Akin to the base of keleuo; to 'call'.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
Pertaining to self, i.e. One's own; by implication, private or separate.
From the base of dokeo; glory, in a wide application.
And, even, also, namely.
Goodness, a gracious act, virtue, uprightness. From the same as arrhen; properly, manliness, i.e. Excellence.
